values.title: Revert pull request #401

values.description:
The XML generated by QTest can break the format expected by the the jenkins performance plugin.

This pull request implements the conversion, using the xsltproc tool and stylesheet defined in:
http://qtnode.net/wiki/QtTest_XML_Output

Conversion is integrated into our check_test_ran.py and the check is using a simple grep. If xsltproc is not installed in the system, the XML output for check_ test will report this lack of proper tool and returning a fail.
values.title: Initial support to convert QTest to Junit

summary.raw:
The XML generated by QTest can break the format expected by the the jenkins performance plugin.

This pull request implements the conversion, using the xsltproc tool and stylesheet defined in:
http://qtnode.net/wiki/QtTest_XML_Output

Conversion is integrated into our check_test_ran.py and the check is using a simple grep. If xsltproc is not installed in the system, the XML output for check_ test will report this lack of proper tool and returning a fail.
summary.html:
The XML generated by QTest can break the format expected by the the jenkins performance plugin.

This pull request implements the conversion, using the xsltproc tool and stylesheet defined in: http://qtnode.net/wiki/QtTest_XML_Output

Conversion is integrated into our check_test_ran.py and the check is using a simple grep. If xsltproc is not installed in the system, the XML output for check_ test will report this lack of proper tool and returning a fail.

values.description:
I tried to split this into multiple pull-requests, but that effort seems to have caused more problems. So, here is everything.

Logging performance should be greatly improved.

This pull-request also includes all the gzlog filtering code from pull request #400.

**Update:**

I'm running the tests through the fancy `gz_build_test.bash` script tonight. I'll post the results tomorrow.

**Update:**

All tests should pass.

Current QTest files were wrapped with QBENCHMARK.

Extra rules to xsl conversion from Qtest -> Junit to be able to pass the benchmark duration as time attribute in junit.

This should allow us to see duration of Qtest in jenkins.

values.description:
This isn't a problem with the boost we're using on Ubuntu (1.46 I think), but this change is required to compile on boost 1.53 on os x. It may break compatibility with boost <= 1.43. I can add #ifdefs if we want to maintain compatibility with old versions of boost.

Referenced in issue #657.

values.description:
The easiest way to test is to change the hokuyo laser model to use `gpu_ray` as its type and comment out the use of `libRayPlugin` in model.sdf

Key changes:

- Fix some cases where the range values are not correct

- Fix instantiating multiple gpu ray sensors

- Add gpu laser unit and integration tests

- Add noise model

- Enable laser scan data publishing

- Add visualization in gzclient

- A bunch of style fixes

Known issue:

- It was found that skyx causes laser range values to be clipped. I did a workaround that just sets it to invisible when doing the first laser rendering pass (line 384 in gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.cc). There maybe another easier/cleaner way to do this but this is sufficient for now to make things work.

Update: 

- Fix sampling of range ranges when gpu ray sensor is pitched or rolled. 

- Added test world file: gpu_laser2.world
values.title: gpu ray sensor

summary.raw:
The easiest way to test is to change the hokuyo laser model to use `gpu_ray` as its type and comment out the use of `libRayPlugin` in model.sdf

Key changes:

- Fix some cases where the range values are not correct

- Fix instantiating multiple gpu ray sensors

- Add gpu laser unit and integration tests

- Add noise model

- Enable laser scan data publishing

- Add visualization in gzclient

- A bunch of style fixes

Known issue:

- It was found that skyx causes laser range values to be clipped. I did a workaround that just sets it to invisible when doing the first laser rendering pass (line 384 in gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.cc). There maybe another easier/cleaner way to do this but this is sufficient for now to make things work.

Update: 

- Fix sampling of range ranges when gpu ray sensor is pitched or rolled. 

- Added test world file: gpu_laser2.world
summary.html:
The easiest way to test is to change the hokuyo laser model to use gpu_ray as its type and comment out the use of libRayPlugin in model.sdf

Key changes:

  • Fix some cases where the range values are not correct

  • Fix instantiating multiple gpu ray sensors

  • Add gpu laser unit and integration tests

  • Add noise model

  • Enable laser scan data publishing

  • Add visualization in gzclient

  • A bunch of style fixes

Known issue:

  • It was found that skyx causes laser range values to be clipped. I did a workaround that just sets it to invisible when doing the first laser rendering pass (line 384 in gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.cc). There maybe another easier/cleaner way to do this but this is sufficient for now to make things work.

Update:

  • Fix sampling of range ranges when gpu ray sensor is pitched or rolled.

  • Added test world file: gpu_laser2.world

values.description:
The GAZEBO_IP_WHITE_LIST is a comma separated list of IP addresses. Only IPs in this list will be accepted. Leaving this env var empty will accept connections from all IPs.

It's hard to write a test for this since it depends on multiple computers. You can test this yourself by running:

On one machine: `GAZEBO_IP_WHITE_LIST=<external_ip> gzserver`

On another machine: `GAZEBO_MASTER_URI=<external_ip>:11345 gzstats`
values.title: GAZEBO_IP_WHITE_LIST environment variable

summary.raw:
The GAZEBO_IP_WHITE_LIST is a comma separated list of IP addresses. Only IPs in this list will be accepted. Leaving this env var empty will accept connections from all IPs.

It's hard to write a test for this since it depends on multiple computers. You can test this yourself by running:

On one machine: `GAZEBO_IP_WHITE_LIST=<external_ip> gzserver`

On another machine: `GAZEBO_MASTER_URI=<external_ip>:11345 gzstats`

values.title: Simplify command-line parsing of gztopic echo output

summary.html:
Add an option to gztopic that prints messages on a single line, which is useful for command-line parsing.

Currently gztopic echo /gazebo/default/world_stats outputs human-readable formatting with messages on multiple lines:

sim_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 218000000
}
pause_time {
  sec: 0
  nsec: 0
}
real_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 363079642
}
paused: false
iterations: 17218

sim_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 413000000
}
pause_time {
  sec: 0
  nsec: 0
}
real_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 563192487
}
paused: false
iterations: 17413

With this pull request, gztopic echo2 /gazebo/default/world_stats would output the following, with each message on a single line:

sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 357000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 198 nsec: 846875458 } paused: false iterations: 197357
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 557000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 199 nsec: 47136552 } paused: false iterations: 197557
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 757000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 199 nsec: 247788813 } paused: false iterations: 197757

For large messages (e.g. /gazebo/default/physics/contacts) the new option is not readable at all, but can be parsed using command-line tools (sed, awk, grep) since each message is on a single line.

I wrote the syntax to minimize changes to the code, so suggestions are welcome for alternatives.

values.reason:
I'm not going to include this for a few reasons:
1) We have received new textures and meshes for the rubble pile. Elements in the rubble pile will consist of actual gazebo models
2) We are trying not include textures in the main gazebo repository. It needlessly increases the size of the gazebo distribution. The textures provided in this branch will be used directly in the VRC worlds, according the pull-request in the DRCSim branch.

values.description:
1. Rendering and physics should match up more closely.

2. Terrain GUI editor. This is only a partial implementation of terrain editing. It's not meant to be perfect, or feature complete. I'm including this code because it refactors the GUI code for editors, and I need some of the changes for other GUI dev work. The terrain editor is disable by default.

Issue #637: The size of the textures in heightmap.world were reduced to 1. There is no code to "fix" this, it's just a matter of specifying SDF parameters differently.

Issue #638: The physics Heightmap class now send height data directly to the rendering engine. There are also some tweaks on the rendering side to disable LOD rendering.

Next steps: Modify the VRC worlds to have smoother terrain with better textures, and test the terrain with Atlas.
values.title: Terrain improvements.

summary.raw:
1. Rendering and physics should match up more closely.

2. Terrain GUI editor. This is only a partial implementation of terrain editing. It's not meant to be perfect, or feature complete. I'm including this code because it refactors the GUI code for editors, and I need some of the changes for other GUI dev work. The terrain editor is disable by default.

Issue #637: The size of the textures in heightmap.world were reduced to 1. There is no code to "fix" this, it's just a matter of specifying SDF parameters differently.

Issue #638: The physics Heightmap class now send height data directly to the rendering engine. There are also some tweaks on the rendering side to disable LOD rendering.

Next steps: Modify the VRC worlds to have smoother terrain with better textures, and test the terrain with Atlas.
summary.html:
1. Rendering and physics should match up more closely.

  2. Terrain GUI editor. This is only a partial implementation of terrain editing. It's not meant to be perfect, or feature complete. I'm including this code because it refactors the GUI code for editors, and I need some of the changes for other GUI dev work. The terrain editor is disable by default.

Issue #637: The size of the textures in heightmap.world were reduced to 1. There is no code to "fix" this, it's just a matter of specifying SDF parameters differently.

Issue #638: The physics Heightmap class now send height data directly to the rendering engine. There are also some tweaks on the rendering side to disable LOD rendering.

Next steps: Modify the VRC worlds to have smoother terrain with better textures, and test the terrain with Atlas.

values.description:
* reduce contact `sor` by half.
 * fix constraint order based on `findex`.
 * disable random constraint row reordering.
 * implement max contacts on a per collision basis.
   * pass through URDF `maxContacts` in extension to SDF `max_contacts` in collision.
 * adaptive cfm damping triggered by negative damping coefficient by adding additional damping when f/v is high. 

**Requires**

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sandia-hand/pull-request/25/tuning-sim-contact-parameters-and-changed/diff
values.title: implement per collision max contacts param and stabilize contacts calculation

summary.raw:
* reduce contact `sor` by half.
 * fix constraint order based on `findex`.
 * disable random constraint row reordering.
 * implement max contacts on a per collision basis.
   * pass through URDF `maxContacts` in extension to SDF `max_contacts` in collision.
 * adaptive cfm damping triggered by negative damping coefficient by adding additional damping when f/v is high. 

**Requires**

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sandia-hand/pull-request/25/tuning-sim-contact-parameters-and-changed/diff
summary.html:
• reduce contact sor by half.
  • fix constraint order based on findex.
  • disable random constraint row reordering.
  • implement max contacts on a per collision basis.
  • pass through URDF maxContacts in extension to SDF max_contacts in collision.
  • adaptive cfm damping triggered by negative damping coefficient by adding additional damping when f/v is high.

Requires

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sandia-hand/pull-request/25/tuning-sim-contact-parameters-and-changed/diff

values.description:
I noticed that real time factor dropped when Atlas interacts with mud. This pull request made two changes to improve performance.

1. The main speed improvement comes from the collide_without_contact_bitmask. Since a mud model sets collide_without_contact to true which allows a collision to penetrate through another, this generated a very large number of contact points. A bitmask is used to filter out contacts that are not specified in the mud plugin.

2. Added a filter feature in contact manager so that it can now limit data generated to only contacts that are needed by the contact sensor. It publishes to a custom topic specific to each contact sensor.

Update: 

- Add mud_bitmask.world demo

- Modify MudPlugin to auto generate bitmask from contact sensor's collision list if none specified
(as per [comment here]( https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/247/integrate-mud-into-vrc_task_2-world#comment-232036))
values.title: Contact changes for mud performance improvement

summary.raw:
I noticed that real time factor dropped when Atlas interacts with mud. This pull request made two changes to improve performance.

1. The main speed improvement comes from the collide_without_contact_bitmask. Since a mud model sets collide_without_contact to true which allows a collision to penetrate through another, this generated a very large number of contact points. A bitmask is used to filter out contacts that are not specified in the mud plugin.

2. Added a filter feature in contact manager so that it can now limit data generated to only contacts that are needed by the contact sensor. It publishes to a custom topic specific to each contact sensor.

Update: 

- Add mud_bitmask.world demo

- Modify MudPlugin to auto generate bitmask from contact sensor's collision list if none specified
(as per [comment here]( https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/247/integrate-mud-into-vrc_task_2-world#comment-232036))
summary.html:
I noticed that real time factor dropped when Atlas interacts with mud. This pull request made two changes to improve performance.

  1. The main speed improvement comes from the collide_without_contact_bitmask. Since a mud model sets collide_without_contact to true which allows a collision to penetrate through another, this generated a very large number of contact points. A bitmask is used to filter out contacts that are not specified in the mud plugin.

  2. Added a filter feature in contact manager so that it can now limit data generated to only contacts that are needed by the contact sensor. It publishes to a custom topic specific to each contact sensor.

Update:

  • Add mud_bitmask.world demo

  • Modify MudPlugin to auto generate bitmask from contact sensor's collision list if none specified (as per comment here)
